citation.article-title: Taxonomy of the genus Acinetobacter with the recognition of Acinetobacter baumannii sp. nov., Acinetobacter haemolyticus sp. nov., Acinetobacter johnsonii sp. nov., and Acinetobacter junii sp. nov., and emended descriptions of Acinetobacter calcoaceticus and Acinetobacter lwoffii.

p.s: Emended description of Acinetobacter calcoaceticus (Beijerinck 1911) Baumann, Doudoroff, and Stanier 1968.
Also called genospecies 1 in this study. Type species of the genus Acinetobacter Brisou and Prévot 1954 (26).
Characteristics as given previously for the genus (19, 20).

Colonies on tryptocasein soy agar are circular, convex, smooth, and slightly opaque with entire margins; colonies are 0.5 to 1.5 mm in diameter after 24 h and 2.5 to 3.5 mm in diameter after 48 h at 30°C.
Good growth occurs at 15 to 37°C in 1 day.
No growth occurs at 41°C and above.
Nitrates are not reduced to nitrites in complex medium.
Grows on citrate (Simmons).
Acid is produced from D-glucose.
γ-Glutamyltransferase is produced, but β-xylosidase is not produced.
Horse or sheep blood is not hemolyzed; gelatin is not hydrolyzed.

The following compounds are utilized as sole sources of carbon and energy: L-phenylalanine, L-histidine, phenylacetate, malonate, azelate, β-alanine, trans-aconitate, L-arginine, L-ornithine, DL-lactate, 2,3-butanediol, DL-4-aminobutyrate, glutarate, L-aspartate, and L-tyrosine.
D-Malate and histamine are not utilized.
L-Leucine is utilized by some strains.
The guanine-plus-cytosine (G+C) content of the DNA is 40 to 42 mol% (as determined by thermal denaturation [17]).
Isolated from soil.
The type strain is strain ATCC 23055 (= CIP 81.08).
Description of the type strain.
Strain ATCC 23055T has all of the characteristics given above for the species.
In addition, this strain does not utilize L-leucine in API-AA strips as a sole source of carbon and energy.
